column1: Use a standard code formatter (e.g., Prettier, Black, gofmt) to automatically fix formatting issues. Configure your IDE to auto-format on save.
Profile the code to identify bottlenecks. Review algorithms for better time/space complexity. Consider alternative data structures.
column4: Inefficient algorithm or data structure usage

column1: Implement robust input validation and sanitization for all user-supplied data. Use parameterized queries for database interactions. Escape outputs for display in web applications.
Write clear, concise comments for complex logic. Add docstrings/Javadocs for functions/methods and classes. Create high-level documentation for modules and systems.
Use a debugger to step through the code. Write unit tests to reproduce and fix the bug, including edge cases and boundary conditions.
column6: Debug and test with edge cases

column1: Set up a linter (e.g., ESLint, Pylint, Checkstyle) with a defined style guide. Integrate it into your CI/CD pipeline to enforce standards.
Identify deprecated components. Consult documentation for migration paths. Update libraries to their latest stable versions. Refactor code using modern alternatives.
column4: Use of outdated libraries or features

column1: Break down large functions into smaller, single-responsibility units. Use dependency injection or inversion of control to reduce coupling between modules.
column4: High cyclomatic complexity or tight coupling

column1: Identify repeated code. Create shared functions, classes, or modules to encapsulate the common logic. Replace duplicated sections with calls to these new components.
Implement appropriate try-catch/try-except blocks for potential error points. Log errors with sufficient detail. Provide user-friendly error messages when necessary.
column4: Unhandled exceptions or inadequate error messages

column1: Use 'finally' blocks, 'with' statements (Python), or 'try-with-resources' (Java) to ensure resources are always closed. Implement explicit dispose methods where automatic cleanup is not available.

Analyze concurrent sections of code. Use locks, semaphores, mutexes, or atomic operations to protect shared resources and prevent race conditions. Implement deadlock detection and prevention strategies.
Implement a structured logging strategy. Use appropriate logging levels (DEBUG, INFO, WARN, ERROR) for different messages. Ensure sensitive information is not logged.
Write unit tests for critical functions and components. Implement integration tests for system interactions. Utilize test coverage tools to identify untested code paths.
column4: Low test coverage or lack of unit tests

column1: Move environment-specific settings (database connections, API endpoints, etc.) out of the codebase into external configuration files (e.g., JSON, YAML, `.env`) or a dedicated configuration service.
column4: Hardcoded values or lack of external configuration

column1: Use memory profiling tools to identify memory leaks or areas of high memory consumption. Optimize data structures and algorithms to reduce memory footprint. Implement object pooling if appropriate.
column4: Memory leaks or excessive memory consumption

column1: Regularly check for updates for all third-party libraries. Use vulnerability scanners (e.g., Dependabot, Snyk) to identify known vulnerabilities. Update or replace vulnerable dependencies.
Identify the cause of poor UX (e.g., slow API calls, blocking UI threads). Implement asynchronous operations, optimize rendering, and provide user feedback for long-running tasks.
column4: Poor user experience due to code (e.g., slow UI)
